Authors:
Vanessa Di Vincenzo, Michael Gruenstaeudl, Lars Nauheimer,
Melaku Wondafrash, Peris Kamau, Sebsebe Demissew, Thomas Borsch
Title:
Evolutionary diversification of the African Achyranthoid
clade (Amaranthaceae) in the context of sterile flower evolution and
epizoochory
Keywords:
Africa, Amaranthaceae, BiSSE, Caryophyllales, character
evolution, epizoochory, floral morphology, HiSSE, phylogeny, species
diversification
Abstract:
Background and Aims Many African genera of the
Amaranthaceae exhibit unique inflorescences that include sterile flowers
modified to hooks or spines. Considering that the abundance of large
terrestrial herbivores increased on the African continent with the
expansion of grassland and savannah ecosystems, modified sterile flowers
could have been an innovation that boosted the diversification of an
African Achyranthoid clade of Amaranthaceae, with large animals serving
dispersal.
